Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Polydipsia, polyuria, polyphagia, and weight loss for 3 months

Present Illness.Onset: Onset 3 months ago, at home, gradual onset, no prodromal symptoms, possible triggers include diet changes and stress
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Excessive thirst, frequent urination, excessive hunger, significant unintentional weight loss, symptoms persistent and worsening over the last 3 months
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Fatigue and blurred vision, symptoms developed concurrently with the main symptoms
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: No previous diagnosis or treatment for current symptoms; first time seeking medical attention for these issues
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Increased fatigue, disrupted sleep due to nocturia, decreased appetite and weight loss, previously stable urination and defecation patterns now altered

Past History.Disease History: Hypertension for 10 years, controlled with medication

Personal History.Living Habits: Quit smoking 15 years ago, drinks alcohol occasionally, regular diet, moderate physical activity
Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Retired teacher, no exposure to occupational hazards
Personal History.Exposure History: No significant exposure to industrial toxins, dust, or radioactive substances

Marital and Family History.Family History: Mother had type 2 diabetes, father had hypertension, siblings healthy

Systematic Examination.Skin: No rashes or lesions, normal turgor
Systematic Examination.Chest: Normal configuration, clear lung fields, normal heart sounds, no murmurs
Systematic Examination.Limbs: No edema, normal range of motion
Systematic Examination.Nervous System: Alert and oriented, cranial nerves intact, motor and sensory functions normal

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Detailed retina examination showed no retinopathy
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Fasting blood glucose: 220 mg/dL, HbA1c: 9.5%, urinalysis: positive for glucose
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Symptoms of polydipsia, polyuria, polyphagia, and weight loss; elevated fasting blood glucose and HbA1c levels, family history of diabetes
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Type 1 diabetes (less likely due to age at onset and gradual development), Type 2 diabetes (more likely given family history and typical presentation)

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient admitted with symptoms of polydipsia, polyuria, polyphagia, and weight loss. Elevated fasting glucose and HbA1c suggest diabetes, likely type 2. Initial plan includes diet modification, metformin, and monitoring blood glucose levels.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Patient responding to metformin, blood glucose levels starting to decrease, education on lifestyle modification provided.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Senior physician concurred with diagnosis and treatment plan, no changes recommended.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Shift change: Patient stable, continue current management plan.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: After 7 days: Blood glucose levels stabilizing, patient educated on diabetes management, ready for discharge with follow-up plan.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Endocrinology consult: Agrees with type 2 diabetes diagnosis and management plan.
Post-Admission Course Records.Discharge Records: Discharged on 25th September, blood glucose under control, scheduled follow-up in two weeks.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: Metformin 500 mg twice daily, diabetic diet, blood sugar monitoring before meals and at bedtime

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: Basic metabolic panel, lipid profile pending
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Normal temperature, stable vitals, no fever observed
